div1.p: We're as set up over John's good luck that already we've celebrated with strawberries and cream, and there is even talk of buying some peanuts. See for yourself that we are having hard work to control our enthusiasm. No, but truly, we are elated. For that salary is sure enough some salary. Outside of editor and managing editor jobs, I know of no place on Omaha papers that draws such a salary as this one of John's. Still, the Journal knows well enough what it's doing. The name of Neihardt is something to be featured.

Another thing that makes us glad is the thought that Mona shall have her opportunity of going on
26
with her artwork. We're anxious to see that, and to see the whole house of Neihardt seem as it should in the art achievement of this crazy, materialistic country.

Long ago I should have told you how very "chesty" I got about your letter telling me that you liked my little boy. It's such mothers as you who understand what a writer is trying to do when he makes a book littl like that. Others, I'm afraid, see in such a tale only something that is slight and fragile and perhaps rather palid. Well, one doesn't write for those others. Some day, though, I hope to have you see something of mine more ambitious in scope and of a deeper significance.
div1.note: Mona and I were married at the house of Keene Abbott
